intro: Rubus hispidus var. setosus, commonly known as the bristly blackberry, is a shrub native to parts of Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that ripen to a dark purple or black color. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in woodland edges and disturbed soils. Botanically, it belongs to the Rosaceae family and is closely related to other bramble species.
